document_title: Thermal Plasticity and Evolutionary Constraints in Bacillus: Implications for Climate Change Adaptation
summary_full: This study investigated the ability of Bacillus bacteria, common in soil and water, to adapt to rising global temperatures due to climate change. Seven strains from two lineages (Bacillus cereus and Bacillus subtilis) were subjected to experimental evolution under gradually increasing temperatures. While some Bacillus subtilis strains showed minor improvements in heat tolerance, none could grow well at temperatures just 3°C above their natural range. Bacillus cereus strains showed higher mutation rates but did not improve heat tolerance. Convergent evolution was observed in five evolved lines, with mutations in genes related to c-di-AMP synthesis, a molecule involved in regulating potassium levels and implicated for the first time in heat tolerance. The findings highlight the vulnerability of essential bacteria to climate change and suggest that their adaptive capacity may be limited, with potential cascading effects on ecosystems.
key_findings: Bacillus bacteria, including B. subtilis and B. cereus, show limited capacity to evolve significant heat tolerance even under gradual temperature increases over 1000 generations.
Only one evolved B. subtilis line successfully extended its thermal niche by 4°C above its natural range.
B. cereus strains exhibited higher mutation rates but failed to adapt to increased temperatures, while B. subtilis showed distinct adaptive strategies.

Convergent mutations in genes regulating c-di-AMP synthesis (cdaR in B. subtilis, disA in B. cereus) were identified in multiple evolved lines, implicating c-di-AMP in heat tolerance for the first time.
Adaptation to higher temperatures in some B. subtilis lines occurred even when evolved at a constant 37°C, suggesting metabolic adjustments influenced by growth conditions.
Evolutionary adaptation to high temperatures often came with trade-offs, such as reduced growth at lower temperatures, particularly in B. cereus.
future_research_fields: Investigating the precise molecular mechanisms by which c-di-AMP regulates heat tolerance in bacteria.
Exploring the role of other compatible solutes and osmolytes in bacterial adaptation to thermal stress.
Assessing the long-term evolutionary potential of bacterial communities under sustained climate change scenarios.
Conducting transcriptomic and proteomic analyses to understand the broader cellular responses to thermal stress in Bacillus.
Examining the impact of these thermal limitations on microbial community function and biogeochemical cycles in natural ecosystems.

conclusions: Bacillus strains exhibit limited thermal adaptation, with lineage-specific outcomes and immediate trade-offs even under prolonged selective pressure. This constrained evolvability has significant implications for microbial responses to global warming, potentially affecting biogeochemical cycles and ecosystem stability. Understanding these evolutionary limits is crucial for predicting the ecological impacts of climate change.
impact_statement: This study reveals that essential soil and water bacteria have limited capacity to adapt to projected climate change temperatures, potentially disrupting critical ecosystem functions.
